content: अंग {%<ab>ind.</ab>%} A vocative particle meaning ‘well,’ ‘well, sir,’ ‘indeed,’ ‘true;’ ‘assent’ (as in अंगीकृ); अंग कच्चित्कुशली तातः <ls>K. 221</ls>; प्रभुरपि जनकानामंग भो याचकस्ते <ls>Mv. 3. 5</ls>; अंग अस्ति कश्चिद्विमर्दको नामात्रभवतः <ls>Dk. 59</ls>; अंग कुरु अंग पच <ls>P. VIII. 1. 33</ls> Sk; अंगाधीष्व भक्तं तव दास्यामि <ls>P. VIII. 2. 96</ls> <ls>Sk.</ls>; समनद्ध किमंग भूपतिः <ls>Śi. 16. 34</ls>, <ls n="Śi.">2. 12</ls>; <ls>Ki. 10. 55</ls>, <ls n="Ki.">13. 65</ls>; used with किं in the sense of ‘how much less’, or ‘how much more;’ शक्तिरस्ति कस्यचिद्विदेहराजस्य छायामप्यवस्कंदितुं किमंग जामातरं <ls>Mv. 3</ls>; तृणेन कार्यं भवतीश्वराणां किमंग वाघस्तवता नरेण <ls>Pt. 1. 71.</ls> Lexicographers give the following senses of अंगः - क्षिप्रे च पुनरर्थे च संगमासूययोस्तथा . हर्षे संबोधने चैव ह्यंगशब्दः प्रयुज्यते ..

अंगं [अम् गत्यादौ बा°--गन्; according to <ls>Nir.</ls> अंगं अंगनात् अंचनात् वा] {@--1@} The body. {@--2@} A limb or member of the body; शेषांगनिर्माणविधौ विधातुः <ls>Ku. 1. 33</ls>; क्लेशस्यांगमदत्त्वा <ls>Pt. 5. 32</ls> without undergoing troubles; इति स्वप्नोपमान्मस्वा कामान्मा गास्तदंगतां . <ls>Ki. 11. 34</ls> do not be influenced or swayed by them (do not be subject to them). {@--3@} ({%<ab>a.</ab>%}) A division or department (of any thing), a part or portion, as of a whole; as सप्तांगं राज्यं, चतुरंगं बलं, चतुःषष्ट्यंगं ज्योतिःशास्त्रं see the words; गीतांगानां <ls>Pt. 5. 56</ls>; यज्ञश्चेत्प्रतिरुद्धःस्यादेकेनांगेन यज्वनः <ls>Ms. 11. 11.</ls> (Hence) ({%b%}.) A supplementary or auxiliary portion, supplement; षडंगः or सांगः वेदः. ({%c%}.) A constituent part, essential requisite or component; सर्वैर्बलांगैः <ls>R. 7. 59</ls>; तदंगमग्र्यं मघवन् महाक्रतोः <ls>R. 3. 46.</ls> ({%d%}.) An attributive or secondary part; secondary, auxiliary or dependent member (serving to help the principal one) (<ab>opp.</ab> प्रधान or अंगिन्); अंगी रौद्ररसस्तत्र सर्वेंऽगानि रसाः पुनः <ls>S. D. 517</ls>; अत्र स्वभावोक्तिरुत्प्रेक्षांगं <ls>Malli.</ls> on <ls>Ki. 8. 26.</ls> ({%e%}.) An auxiliary means or expedient ( प्रधानोपयोगी उपायः or उपकरणं); सर्वकार्यशरीरेषु मुक्त्वांगस्कंधपंचकं . मंत्रो योध इवाधीरः सर्वांगैः संवृतैरपि .. <ls>Śi. 2. 28-29</ls>; See अंगांगि, पंचांग also (the {%angas%} of the several sciences or departments of knowledge will be given under those words). {@--4@} (Gram.) A name for the base of a word; यस्मात्प्रत्ययविधिस्तदादिप्रत्यये अंगं <ls>P. I. 4. 13</ls>; यः प्रत्ययो यस्मात्क्रियते तदादिशब्दस्वरूपं तस्मिन्प्रत्यये परे अंगसंज्ञं स्यात् <ls>Sk.</ls> The अंग terminations are those of the nominative, and accusative singular and dual. {@--5@} (Drama) ({%<ab>a.</ab>%}) One of the sub-divisions of the five joints or sandhis in dramas; the मुख has 12, प्रतिमुख 13, गर्भ 12, विमर्ष 13 and उपसंहार 14, the total number of the {%angas%} being thus 64; for details see the words. ({%b%}.) The whole body of subordinate characters. {@--6@} (Astr.) A name for the position of stars (लग्न), See अंगाधीश. {@--7@} A symbolical expression for the number six (derived from the six Vedāṅgas). {@--8@} The mind; हिरण्यगर्भांगभुवं मुनिं हरिः <ls>Śi. 1. 1</ls>, See अंगज also. --गः (<ab>pl.</ab>) <ab>N.</ab> of a country and the people inhabiting it, the country about the modern Bhāgalpur in Bengal. [It lay on the south of Kauśikī Kaccha and on the right bank of the Ganges. Its capital was Campā, sometimes called Aṅgapurī, Lomapādapurī, Karṇapurī or Mālinī. According to Daṇḍin (अंगेषु गंगातटे बहिश्चंपायाः) and Hiouen Thsang it stood on the Ganges about 24 miles west of a rocky island. General Cunningham has shown that this description applies to the hill opposite Pātharghātā, that it is 24 miles east of Bhāgalpur, and that there are villages called Champanagar and Champapura adjoining the last. According to Sanskrit poets the country of the Aṅgas lay to the east of Girivraja the capital of Magadha and to the north-east or south-east of Mithilā. The country was in ancient times ruled by Karṇa.] {%--<ab>a.</ab>%} {@--1@} Contiguous. {@--2@} Having members or divisions.

अंग <ab>N.</ab> of an important kingdom situated on the right bank of the Ganges. Its capital was Campā, also called Aṅgapurī. This town stood on the Ganges about 24 miles west of a rocky island, and is, therefore, considered to be the same as, or situated very near, the modern Bhāgalpur.
